arm_group.description: After intravenous infusion of dexmedetomidine for 2 min, propofol 2.0 mg/kg was administrated. And laryngeal mask airway device was inserted(LMA # 3,4).

brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators attempted to determine the optimal dose of dexmedetomidine required for
      the successful insertion of LMA during propofol induction without a neuromuscular blocking
      agent.

clinical_study.brief_title: Dexmedetomidine for Laryngeal Mask Airway Insertion

detailed_description.textblock:
After a predetermined bolus dose of dexmedetomidine was injected over 2 min, anesthesia was
      induced with propofol 2.0 mg/kg.  After confirming the loss of eyelash reflex and the
      bispectral index (BIS) score decreased below 60, the insertion of LMA was attempted.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  ASA I-II patients undergoing general anesthesia for short elective surgery (<1 hr)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  G-E reflux

          -  obesity (BMI>30)

          -  anticipated difficult airway

intervention.description: The dose of dexmedetomidine was determined by modified Dixon's up-and-down method, starting from 0.5 μg/kg (0.1 μg/kg as a step size).
The insertion of laryngeal mask airway (LMA) was attempted, after confirming the loss of eyelash reflex,the bispectral index (BIS) score decreased below 60.

clinical_study.official_title: Optimal Dose of Dexmedetomidine for Laryngeal Mask Airway Insertion During Propofol Induction

primary_outcome.description: the response of patients to the insertion of LMA (classified as either 'movement' or 'no movement') during infusion of dexmedetomidine and propofol.
primary_outcome.time_frame: from baseline to 2 min after insertion of LMA (participants will be followed for the duration of anesthetic induction, an expected average of 10 min).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

results_reference.citation: Uzümcügil F, Canbay O, Celebi N, Karagoz AH, Ozgen S. Comparison of dexmedetomidine-propofol vs. fentanyl-propofol for laryngeal mask insertion. Eur J Anaesthesiol. 2008 Aug;25(8):675-80. doi: 10.1017/S0265021508004213. Epub 2008 Apr 10.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Treatment
